title: Defunct robo adviser claims rules 'unworkable'
text:
ASIC was also concerned that there may have been a conflict between client goals and the recommendations offered by the algorithm.

“Digital advice tools offer a convenient and low-cost alternative to consumers who may otherwise not seek personal financial advice," Ms Press said.

"However, the advice provided through these tools must meet the same legal obligations required of human advisers – the advice must be appropriate to the client and comply with the best interests duty."

Best interest duty 'unworkable' for robo

While ASIC has highlighted its role in raising concerns about the tools, the founders say they voluntarily shut down the businesses due to onerous regulations and resignation of co-founder Josh Golombick, a former UBS research analyst.

"We have formed the view that it is overly challenging to provide holistic digital advice within the constraints of the existing regulatory framework," the co-founders said in a statement.

"Unfortunately, the further steps we would need to take (over and above the extensive steps we have already taken both proactively and responsively) would not be commercially viable for us at this point in time."

A spokesperson for LimeFS clarified to The Australian Financial Review that the founders believed the application of the best interests duty,

introduced under the Future of Financial Advice reforms in 2012, to non-human, automated advice tools is "unworkable".

Advertisement

It is not reasonable, the spokesperson said, to expect a robo-advice tool aimed at low balance consumers to be able to monitor the quality of data input to the same degree as a human advisory business, the spokesperson said.

"If Australia wants a thriving robo-advice market then the regulatory framework will need to change," the spokesperson said.

"The real loser here are Australian consumers, who are unable to access affordable financial advice, with the cost of regulation pushing up the price of human advice."

Plenty Wealth and Plenty Plus had completed approximately 700 statements of advice (SOAs) since launching in 2014.

The closure of the two businesses follows ASIC raising concerns about the number of low balance consumers establishing self-managed superannuation funds, urging SMSF trustees with balances of less than $500,000 to consider whether they might be better off in an industry or retail fund.
description: The founders of now defunct Plenty Wealth and Plenty Plus tools claim the best-interest duty that applies to human financial advisers is "unworkable" for robo advisers. ASIC disagrees.
